subsection.title: Arithmetic Sequences
subsection.p:
A charter tour bus service charges $50 plus $15 for each passenger. The cost of a tour is then a function of the number of passengers. Because the number of passengers, n, can only be a positive integer, the function is a sequence. If C_n represents the cost of a tour for passengers, then
\begin{aligned}[t] C_1 \amp = 50 + 15(1)= 65\\ C_2 \amp = 50 + 15(2) = 80\\ C_3 \amp = 50 + 15(3) = 95\\ \end{aligned} and in general C_n = 50 + 15n

Each term of this sequence can be obtained from the previous one by adding 15. A sequence in which each term can be obtained from the previous term by adding a fixed amount is called an arithmetic sequence.

The fixed amount that we add to each term is the difference between two successive terms and is called the common difference. In the example above the common difference is 15. If we denote the first term of an arithmetic sequence by a and the common difference by d, then the sequence can be defined recursively by
\begin{aligned}[t] a_1 \amp = a\\ a_{n+1} \amp = a_n + d\\ \end{aligned}

statement.p: Find the first four terms of an arithmetic sequence with first term 6 and common difference 3.
Find the first four terms of an arithmetic sequence with first term 100 and common difference -30.

subsection.title: The General Term of an Arithmetic Sequence

assemblage.title: Arithmetic Sequence
assemblage.p: The n^{\text{th}} term of an arithmetic sequence is a_n = a + (n-1)d

subsection.p: We can use this formula to find a particular term of an arithmetic sequence if we know the first term and the common difference.

statement.p: Find the fourteenth term of the arithmetic sequence -6,~-1,~4,~\cdots

solution.p: First, we find the common difference by subtracting any term from its successor: d = -1 - (-6) = 5 Then we use the formula with n = 14 : a_{14}= -6 + (14-1)(5)= 59

statement.p: Find the 100th term of the arithmetic sequence 1, 3, 5, 7, \cdots.
You deposit $8000 in an account that pays 5% simple annual interest.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find a formula for the amount of money in the account after n years.
How much money will be in the account after 20 years?

ol.label: a
ol.li: Each year, 0.05(8000) or $400 interest is added to the account balance. Thus, the annual balances, b_n, form an arithmetic sequence whose first term is 8400 and whose common difference is 400. Hence, b_n = 8400 + (n-1)400
We substitute n=20 into the formula for the general term found in part (a). b_{20} = 8400 + (19)400 = 16,000 After 20 years there will be $16,000 in the account.

subsection.title: Geometric Sequences
subsection.p: A national junior chess tournament starts with 1024 invited contestants. At the end of each round, the winners move on to the next level. Thus, after each round there are half as many contestants as before, and the number of remaining contestants is a function of the number of rounds completed. Because the number of rounds n is a positive integer, the function is a sequence.

Each term of the sequence defined above can be obtained from the previous one by multiplying by \dfrac{1}{2}. A sequence in which each term can be obtained from the previous term by multiplying by a fixed amount is called a geometric sequence.

The fixed amount we multiply each term by is the ratio of two successive terms and is called the common ratio. In the example above the common ratio is \dfrac{1}{2}. If we denote the first term of a geometric sequence by a and the common ratio by r, then the sequence can be defined recursively by
\begin{aligned}[t] a_1 \amp = a\\ a_{n+1} \amp = r a_n\\ \end{aligned}

statement.p: Find the first four terms of a geometric sequence whose first term is 64 and whose common ratio is \dfrac{5}{4}.
Find the first four terms of a geometric sequence whose first term is 5 and whose common ratio is 2.

subsection.p: A geometric sequence defines an exponential function of n. In the figure below, compare the graphs of the exponential function f(x) = 100(2)^{x-1}, whose domain is the set of real numbers, and the geometric sequence a_n = 100(2)^{n-1}, whose domain is the set of positive integers.

note.p: Notice that the common ratio of the geometric sequence corresponds to the base of the exponential function.

subsection.p: Recall that an arithmetic sequence defines a linear function whose slope corresponds to the common difference. Just as an exponential function grows much faster in the long run than a linear function, so does a geometric sequence grow much faster than an arithmetic sequence.

subsection.title: The General Term of a Geometric Sequence
subsection.p:
We can now find a non-recursive formula for the general term of a geometric sequence. If we denote the first term of the geometric sequence by a, then the
\begin{aligned}[t] \text{second term is}~~~~~~ \amp ar\\ \text{third term is}~~~~~~ \amp ar \cdot r = ar^2\\ \text{fourth term is}~~~~~~ \amp ar^2 \cdot r = ar^3\\ n^{\text{th}}~ \text{term is}~~~~~~ \amp ar^{n-1}\\ \end{aligned}
In general we have the following property.

assemblage.title: Geometric Sequence
assemblage.p: The n^{\text{th}} term of a geometric sequence is a_n = ar^{n-1}

subsection.p: We can use the formula to find a particular term of a geometric sequence if we know the first term and the common ratio.

statement.p: Find the ninth term of the geometric sequence -24,~12,~-6,~\cdots.
Find the 12th term of the arithmetic sequence \dfrac{3}{32},~\dfrac{3}{16},~dfrac{3}{8},~ \dfrac{3}{4},~\cdots
You deposit $8000 in an account that pays 5% annual interest compounded annually.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find a formula for the amount of money in the account after n years.
How much money will be in the account after 20 years?

ol.label: a
ol.li: Each year, the account balance is multiplied by 1.05. Thus, the annual balances c_n form a geometric sequence whose first term is 8400 and whose common ratio is 1.05. Hence, c_n = 8400(1.05)^{n-1}
We substitute n = 20 into the formula for the general term found in part (a). c_{20} = 8400(1.05)^{19} = 21,226.38164 After 20 years, there will be $21,226.38 in the account.

li.p: From the definition we see that the first few terms of the sequence are 2, 5, 8, and 11. Because each new term is found by adding 3 to the previous term, we see that this is an arithmetic sequence with a common difference of 3. This means that the sequence has the form a_n = 2 + (n-1)3~~~\text{or}~~~~a_n = 3n - 1

The first four terms of this sequence are 2, 6, 18, and 54. Because each new term is found by multiplying the previous term by 3, we see that this is a geometric sequence with a common ratio of 3. This means that the sequence has the form b_n = 3\cdot 2^{n-1}
